content: Claude Code is the highest leverage skill you can learn this year.
The future of design is here.

A designer, not a developer, built a personal website with an AI chat and a growth design tool in 48 hours using Claude Code, demonstrating the tool's ability to enable rapid product deployment for non-developers.
Claude Code is a coding agent that writes code based on plain English instructions.
When using Claude Code, understanding what you're building is more important than understanding syntax.
Claude Code is considered better than Cursor or other similar tools as of today.
A Tetris game was built using only Figma MCP connected to FigJam and then to Claude Code, without any manual design or coding.
An internal growth design tool with a database, user authentication, and AI-powered recommendations was built and deployed live on the internet in 3 days, attracting over 500 users.
Install Claude Code on Mac by running `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code` in Terminal, ensuring Node.js is installed first if npm is unavailable.
Verify Claude Code installation by typing `claude` in the terminal; it should launch a text interface.
Alternatively, download the Claude Code desktop Mac app, which requires an Anthropic account.

Basic terminal commands for Claude Code include `claude` (start), `cd folder-name` (navigate in), `cd ..` (navigate out), `ls` (list files Mac), `dir` (list files Windows), and `pwd` (show current location Mac).
To start a new project with Claude Code, create a directory using `mkdir my-portfolio`, navigate into it with `cd my-portfolio`, and then launch Claude Code with `claude`.

Always start a Claude Code project by asking for a plan, specifying requirements and desired outputs like tech stack, file structure, design considerations, and a step-by-step implementation plan in a `plan.md` file.
Adjust the project plan generated by Claude Code by providing specific instructions, such as changing the tech stack to vanilla HTML/CSS instead of React.
Implement a project in Claude Code by instructing it to follow the `plan.md`, starting with HTML structure and then adding CSS styling.
Preview a local Claude Code project in a browser by running `npx serve` and opening `http://localhost:3000`.

Iterate on Claude Code projects by providing specific styling, responsiveness, and functionality prompts, such as making a hero section full-height, adding padding, creating hover effects, changing fonts, implementing responsive layouts, adding smooth scrolling, or integrating contact forms.

Commit Claude Code projects to GitHub by initializing git and connecting to a repository using either a direct Claude Code instruction or manual commands: `git init`, `git remote add origin <repo_url>`, `git add .`, `git commit -m "Initial commit"`, and `git push -u origin main`.

Create documentation for a Claude Code project by instructing it to generate a `README.md` explaining the project and how to run it locally, and a `claude.md` describing the architecture and context for future sessions.
Deploy a Claude Code project to Vercel either through the Vercel dashboard by importing the GitHub repository or by instructing Claude Code directly to deploy.
To deploy a project to Vercel via the dashboard: click Add New → Project, import your GitHub repository, then click Deploy.
Once deployed to Vercel, every future push to GitHub will automatically trigger a new deployment.

Add a custom domain to a Vercel-deployed project by going to Settings > Domains in Vercel, adding the domain, and then updating DNS records at the domain provider with the provided A and CNAME records.
To add a custom domain in Vercel: go to Settings → Domains, add your domain (e.g., yourname.com), and then update DNS records at your domain provider with the provided A and CNAME records.

When expanding a static site into a web app with features like Google sign-in, an AI chat widget, and a comment section, research the best approach and create an implementation-plan.md covering services needed (auth, database, AI), architecture overview, security considerations, and step-by-step implementation phases.

Create a .env file for storing API keys (e.g., SUPABASE_URL, SUPABASE_ANON_KEY, OPENAI_API_KEY) and ensure it is excluded from GitHub using a .gitignore file to prevent committing sensitive information.
To set up Supabase for a new project: create a project on supabase.com, then copy the Project URL and anon key from Settings → API.

To enable Google sign-in with Supabase: enable Google as a provider in Supabase (Authentication → Providers), then create an OAuth Client ID in Google Cloud Console (APIs & Services → Credentials) and copy the Client ID back to Supabase.

To securely store an OpenAI API key for server-side use, add it as a secret in Supabase Edge Functions (Settings → Edge Functions → Add Secret) with a name like OPENAI_API_KEY and its corresponding value, ensuring it is never exposed to users.
When implementing a web app with Supabase for auth/database and OpenAI for chat, prioritize authentication, then add the AI chat feature, and finally the comment system, using Google sign-in only.
A planning prompt for AI involves asking it to research how to build a specific component and create a plan.md with tech stack, structure, and implementation steps.
An implementation prompt for AI involves instructing it to implement a project according to a plan.md, specifying a starting component.
A prompt for adding features to a project involves specifying the feature, its desired behavior, and any necessary services or APIs.
A debugging prompt for AI involves providing an error message (optionally with a screenshot) and asking the AI to find and fix the issue.

The Vibe-Coding course includes installation walkthroughs (Mac + Windows), interface orientation, a first project tutorial, GitHub + version control, Vercel deployment, custom domains, Supabase + OpenAI integration, and bonus chapters on AI agents and Figma MCP.
Designers should learn to build, as it empowers them to bring their ideas to reality without relying on others.
